revision.text:
The '''Plebs' League''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] educational and political organisation which originated around a [[Marxist]] way of thinking in 1908 and was active until 1926.
Central to the formation of the League was [[Noah Ablett]], a [[miner]] from the [[Rhondda]] who was at the core of a group at [[Ruskin College, Oxford]] who challenged the lecturers' opposition to Marxism. In the 1907–8 academic year, Ablett began leading unofficial classes in Marxist [[political economy]] which were attended by [[Ebby Edwards]], among others. Ablett returned to South Wales in 1908, where he began promoting Marxist education through local branches of the [[Independent Labour Party]].<ref name="pitt">[http://www.whatnextjournal.co.uk/Pages/History/Nextstep.html Syndicalism in South Wales], Bob Pitt</ref>
A mixture of students and former students at Ruskin founded the Plebs' League in November 1908, also launching the ''Plebs' Magazine''.<ref>''Proletcult'', Eden Paul (1921)</ref> In the first issue of the ''Plebs'', dated February 1909, Ablett contributed an article on the need for independent [[working class education]].<ref>''Biographical Dictionary of European Labor Leaders'', A. T. Lane (1995), p. 3</ref> The League ran classes teaching Marxist principles and later [[syndicalism|syndicalist]] ideas.<ref name="welsh">''The Welsh Academy Encyclopaedia of Wales''. [[John Davies (historian)|John Davies]], [[Nigel Jenkins]], Menna Baines and Peredur Lynch (2008), p. 687 {{ISBN|978-0-7083-1953-6}}</ref>
During 1909, student agitation for Marxism continued at Ruskin. The students were supported by the Principal, [[Dennis Hird]], and when he was dismissed the students went on strike, refusing to attend classes. The rebels formed the [[Central Labour College]], which worked closely with the Plebs' League.<ref name="welsh" />
By 1910, the Plebs' League was active in South Wales, Lancashire and Scotland. Activists included [[A. J. Cook (trade unionist)|A. J. Cook]], [[William Mainwaring]], [[Mark Starr (labor educationalist)|Mark Starr]] and [[John Maclean (Scottish socialist)|John Maclean]].<ref name="pitt" /><ref>[http://www.marxists.org/archive/hallas/works/1986/12/ruskin.htm The Ruskin Debate: Their college or ours?], ''Socialist Worker Review 93'', [[Duncan Hallas]] (1986)</ref>
The League had sympathies with [[De Leonism]], primarily represented in Britain by the [[Socialist Labour Party (UK, 1903)|Socialist Labour Party]]. It later had a relationship with the [[Communist Party of Great Britain]].<ref name="barberis">''Encyclopedia of British and Irish Political Organizations'', Peter Barberis, John McHugh and Mike Tyldesley (2000), p. 157</ref>
The League was absorbed by the [[National Council of Labour Colleges]] the year after the [[1926 United Kingdom general strike]], although the ''Plebs' Magazine'' continued to appear for many years.<ref name="barberis" />
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://cymru1914.org/en/view/publisher/4006241 Archive of 26 issues from February 1915 - January 1917]
[[Category:Organizations established in 1909]] [[Category:1927 disestablishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Marxism]] [[Category:Socialist education]] [[Category:Political organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1909 establishments in the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox software | name = Popexpert | logo = <!-- Image name is enough. --> | logo alt = | logo caption = | screenshot = <!-- Image name is enough. --> | screenshot alt = | caption = | collapsible = <!-- Any text here will collapse the screenshot. --> | author = | developer = Ingrid Sanders | released = 2012 | discontinued = <!-- Set to yes if software is discontinued, otherwise omit. --> | ver layout = <!-- simple (default) or stacked --> | latest release version = | latest release date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | status = | programming language = | operating system = | platform = | size = | language = | language count = <!-- Number only --> | language footnote = | genre = Online learning platform | license = | alexa = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.org}} --> | repo = <!-- {{URL|example.org}} --> | standard = | AsOf = }}
'''Popexpert''' is an online learning platform that allows users to connect face-to-face with experts in a variety of subject areas.<ref>Markel, Katrina. [http://www.siliconprairienews.com/2014/05/ingrid-sanders-wants-you-to-take-a-sabbatical-to-refresh-your-thinking "Ingrid Sanders wants you to take a sabbatical to refresh your thinking"] ''[[Silicon Prairie]]'' May 9, 2014. Retrieved on June 10, 2014.</ref> The experience all takes place on the Popexpert site, allowing users to book, pay, and video chat all from their accounts.<ref>Swallow, Erica. [http://mashable.com/2013/10/16/popexpert/ "PopExpert Connects You With Online Video Advice From Experts Worldwide"] ''[[Mashable]]'' October 16, 2013. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> Not unlike [[CreativeLive]], [[Skillshare]].com, and Lynda.com, Popexpert’s “Life, Work, and Play” categories are geared towards emotional intelligence and personal development.<ref>Swallow, Erica. [https://www.americanexpress.com/us/small-business/openforum/articles/3-awesome-sites-for-feeding-your-brain/ "3 Awesome Sites For Feeding Your Brain"] ''[[American Express]] open forum'' September 11, 2013. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> Popexpert is currently based at 1020 Kearny Street in San Francisco, California.
== Services == Popexpert connects experts with users through curated courses and one on one sessions.
=== Courses === In 2014, Popexpert began offering video classes by its cache of experts, jumpstarted by Carrie Hammer's "Role Models not Runway Models" master course <ref>Biggs, Claire. [http://www.iamthatgirl.com/carrie_hammer_s_real_role_model_challenge "Carrie Hammer's Real Role Model Challenge"] ''Iamthatgirl.com'' Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref><ref>Moore, Christina. [https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbesstylefile/2014/03/06/designer-spotlight-carrie-hammer-fuses-beauty-and-brains/ "Designer Spotlight: Carrie Hammer Fuses Beauty and Brains"], ''[[Forbes]]'', March 6, 2014. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> and [[Shauna Shapiro]] and Pediatrician Chris White's "Mindful Discipline" workshop.
=== Individual sessions === Experts in [[Meditation]], [[Nutrition]], Personal Style, [[Career Development]], and many other disciplines can be found in Popexpert's Live, Work, and Play categories.<ref>Fowler, Brandi. [http://www.eonline.com/news/498617/golden-globes-red-carpet-trend-alert-5-tips-on-how-to-rock-red-lips "Golden Globes Red Carpet Trend Alert: How to Get Glam Red Lips"], ''[[E! Online]]'', January 13, 2014. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> Sessions with experts typically last fifty minutes and offer a personalized experience.<ref>Israel, Shel. [https://www.forbes.com/sites/shelisrael/2014/05/27/ressurecting-trust-table-of-contents/ "Resurrecting Trust: Table of Contents"], ''[[Forbes]]'', May 27, 2014. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> They use a video platform that allows users to type and save notes for future study.<ref>Swallow, Erica. [http://mashable.com/2013/10/16/popexpert/ "PopExpert Connects You With Online Video Advice From Experts Worldwide" ''[[Mashable]]'' October 16, 2013. Retrieved June 11, 2014.]</ref> Notable experts include [[Ashton Kutcher]], Latham Thomas, and Mikaela Reuben <ref>Grossberg, Josh. [http://www.eonline.com/news/477753/ashton-kutcher-is-a-popexpert-star-giving-face-to-face-career-advice-for-5 "Ashton Kutcher is a PopExpert: Star Giving Face-to-Face Career Advice for $5!"], ''[[E! Online]]'', November 5, 2013. June 11, 2014.</ref> among other celebrities and academics.
== History == Popexpert was founded in 2012 by "Entrepreneur to watch"<ref>Iliff, Rebekah. [http://www.entrepreneur.com/slideshow/232205#4 "SXSW's Entrepreneurs to Watch"], ''[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]]'', March 17, 2014. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> [[Ingrid Sanders]] after a life changing sabbatical inspired her to try and change the world through education.<ref>Soto, Jorge. [http://sales4startups.org/entrepreneurship-with-intention/ "PopExpert CEO: Entrepreneurship with Intention"], ''Sales4Startups.org'', December 21, 2013. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref><ref>Sanders, Ingrid. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ingrid-sanders/find-a-sabbatical-at-home-or-away_b_4020026.html "Find a Sabbatical at Home or Away"], ''[[Huffington Post]]'' October 2, 2013. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> She was soon joined by [[Paypal]] co-founder [[Ken Howery]] and former colleague Jeremy Thomas, who came on as CTO.<ref>Bruzzese, Anita. [https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/columnist/bruzzese/2014/02/02/on-the-job-learn-from-experts/5050969/ "On the Job: Hire experts without hefty consultant's fee"], ''[[USA Today]]'', February 2, 2014. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> After a year, the Popexpert team had developed relationships with over 2,000 of the best experts in [[Emotional Quotient|EQ]] topics.<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/popexpert-the-live-face-to-face-video-marketplace-for-experts-extends-offering-by-featuring-curated-content-and-videos-from-top-experts-to-help-you-get-better-at-life-work--play-230488911.html "popexpert, the live face-to-face video marketplace for experts, extends offering by featuring curated content and videos from top experts to help you get better at life, work & play"], ''[[PR Newswire]]'', November 4, 2013. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> They raised a $50k seed round November 28, 2012 followed immediately by another $450k December 14, 2012. By May 21, 2013 Popexpert secured both $1.7M and $2M in funding for an overall total of $4.20M.<ref>http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/popexpert ''[[CrunchBase]]'', Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> A sample of Popexpert's investors include Learn Capital, BoxGroup, Expansion Venture Capital, [[Ken Howery]], [[Michael Chasen]], Jonathan Segal, Capricorn Investment Group, David Tisch, Noah and Jonah Goodhart, Miki and Radha Agrawal, Mark Ein, Justin Dangel, Jeremy Hinman, [[Nivio]] founder Sachin Duggal,<ref>[http://www.finsmes.com/2013/05/popexpert-raises-2m-funding.html "PopExpert Raises $2M in Funding]", May 21, 2013. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref> and Mike Walsh.<ref>Walsh, Mike. [https://blogs.wsj.com/accelerators/2014/04/17/mike-walsh-investing-in-sharing-startups-since-the-70s/ "Mike Walsh: Investing in 'Sharing' Startups Since the 70s]", ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]", April 17, 2014. Retrieved June 11, 2014.</ref>In April 2016, According to [[The Wall Street Journal]], It was reported that PopExpert Filed for Bankruptcy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/tech-startup-popexpert-files-for-bankruptcy-to-look-for-buyers-1461096764|title=Tech Startup PopExpert Files for Bankruptcy to Look for Buyers|last=|first=|date=April 19, 2016|website=|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:E-learning]]

revision.comment: Alter: title. Add: title-link. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]].
revision.text:
'''Posthegemony''' or '''post-hegemony''' is a period or a situation in which [[hegemony]] is no longer said to function as the organizing principle of a national or post-national [[social order]], or of the relationships between and amongst [[nation state]]s within the global order.{{sfnp|Williams|2002|p=327|ps=: "Posthegemony ... is no longer a name for the hegemony of transnational capital, but the name of those 'places in which hegemony ceases to make sense' (Jean Franco)."}} The concept has different meanings within the fields of [[political theory]], [[cultural studies]], and [[international relations]]. ==In cultural studies== In the field of [[cultural studies]], posthegemony has been developed as a concept by a number of critics whose work engages with and critiques the use of [[cultural hegemony]] theory within the writings of [[Ernesto Laclau]] and within [[subaltern studies]].For example, see {{harvp|Yúdice|1995}}, {{harvp|Moreiras|2001}}, {{harvp|Williams|2002}}, and {{harvp|Beasley-Murray|2010}}. George Yúdice, in 1995, was one of the first commentators to summarize the background to the emergence of this concept:
Flexible accumulation, consumer culture, and the "new world information order" are produced or distributed (made to flow) globally, to occupy the space of the nation, but are no longer "motivated" by any essential connections to a state, as embodied, for example, in a "national-popular" formation. Their motivations are both infra- and [[Supranational union|supranational]]. '''We might say that, from the purview of the national proscenium, a posthegemonic situation holds.''' That is, the "compromise solution" that culture provided for Gramsci is not now one that pertains to the national level but to the local and transnational. Instead, the "culture-ideology of consumerism" serves to naturalize global capitalism everywhere [emphasis added].{{sfnp|Yúdice|1995|p=4}}
The concept of posthegemony is related to the rise of the "[[multitude]]" as a social force which, unlike the "people", cannot be captured by [[hegemony]], together with the roles of [[affect (philosophy)|affect]] and [[habitus (sociology)|habitus]] in mechanisms of social control and agency.These ideas are discussed extensively in {{harvp|Hardt|Negri|2000}}, {{harvp|Hardt|Negri|2004}}, and {{harvp|Beasley-Murray|2010}}. Posthegemony and its related terms are influenced by [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]], [[Pierre Bourdieu]] and [[Michael Hardt]] and [[Antonio Negri]]’s accounts of the supra- and infra-national forces that are said to have rendered obsolete the national-popular forms of coercion and consent through which, for [[Antonio Gramsci]], hegemony structured and constituted society. The features of posthegemony as a concept correspond closely to those of [[postmodernity]]. Thus, posthegemony theory argues that ideology is no longer a political driving force in mechanisms of social control and that the modernist theory of hegemony, which depends on ideology, therefore no longer accurately reflects the [[social order]].{{sfnp|Beasley-Murray|2003|p=119}} Some commentators also argue that history is not, as [[Karl Marx]] described it, a [[class struggle]], but rather a "struggle to produce class".{{sfnp|Beasley-Murray|2003|p=120}} The concept of posthegemony also resonates with the work of post-[[Michel Foucault|Foucauldian]] theorists such as [[Giorgio Agamben]]. Nicholas Thoburn, drawing on Agamben's discussion on the "state of exception", writes that "it is, perhaps, with the recasting of the relationship between law and politico-military and economic crises and interventions that is instituted in the state of exception that the time of hegemony is most revealed to have passed."{{sfnp|Thoburn|2007|p=89}} == In international relations == In [[international relations]], ''posthegemony'' refers to the decline of the US [[Unilateralism|unilateral]] hegemony. This has likely been the result of the difficulties that have arisen out of the unilateral style [[foreign policy]]. These difficulties predominantly include disdain from; those directly affected by the, sometimes forceful, hegemonic actions of the US, those who spectated the actions, and even Americans themselves who view the actions of their government as immoral. For example, after the [[Vietnam War]], in 1978, 72 per cent of Americans thought the war was not a mistake but fundamentally wrong and immoral.{{sfnp|Hagopian|2009|p=13}} This exemplifies the hegemonic decline: how could the US maintain the legitimacy of their interventions if their own citizens find them wrong and immoral?{{tone inline|date=June 2018}} The dominant power(s) of the world is/are fluid, the initial period of US unilateralism can be loosely pinpointed to their interventions during the world wars.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} Following this period of rising US dominance on the world stage, {{quote|there have been no shortage of people who, from the rise of the [Soviet Union's] space programme in the 1950s, through to the third world revolutions of the 1960s and 1970s in Vietnam, Iran and elsewhere, and to the emergence of Japan, Europe and now China as major economic powers, have predicted that US dominance, predominance, hegemony or, in more recent, [[post–Cold War era|post–Cold War]] terms, "unipolarity", are ebbing away.{{sfnp|Halliday|2008|p=12}}}} The predictions of these individuals represent the fluidity of power over time, through the idea that, during the period where the US was unequivocally dominant, people could still see the inevitable future, of a change in power and authority, on the world stage. ==Criticism== Among the criticisms of the theory of posthegemony is Richard Johnson's, that it involves "a marked reduction of social complexity."{{sfnp|Johnson|2007|p=102}} Johnson concedes that "one considerable achievement of 'the post-hegemony project' is to draw many observable [[post-9/11]] features into a single imaginative picture, while also synthesizing different currents in contemporary social theory." But he argues that "it is strange, however, that the result is viewed as the end of hegemony rather than as a new hegemonic moment."{{sfnp|Johnson|2007|p=102}} He, therefore, calls for a rejuvenation of the concept of hegemony, rather than its abandonment. ==See also== * [[Postnationalism]] * [[James C. Scott]] == Notes == {{reflist|22em}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin|35em|indent=yes}} : {{cite journal |last=Beasley-Murray |first=Jon |year=2003 |title=On Posthegemony |journal=Bulletin of Latin American Research |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=117–125 |doi=10.1111/1470-9856.00067 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Beasley-Murray |first=Jon |author-mask={{long dash}} |year=2010 |title=Posthegemony: Political Theory and Latin America |location=Minneapolis, Minnesota |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |isbn=978-0-8166-4714-9 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Hagopian |first=Patrick |year=2009 |title=The Vietnam War in American Memory: Veterans, Memorials, and the Politics of Healing |location=Amherst, Massachusetts |publisher=University of Massachusetts Press |isbn=978-1-55849-693-4 |ref=harv }} : {{cite speech |last=Halliday |first=Fred |author-link=Fred Halliday |year=2008 |title=International Relations in a Post-Hegemonic Age |url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/assets/richmedia/channels/publicLecturesAndEvents/transcripts/20080130_FredHalliday_tr.pdf |event=Valedictory Lecture as Montague Burton Professor of International Relations |location=London |publisher=London School of Economics and Political Science |access-date=10 June 2018 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last1=Hardt |first1=Michael |author1-link=Michael Hardt |last2=Negri |first2=Antonio |author2-link=Antonio Negri |year=2000 |title=Empire |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-674-25121-2 |ref=harv |title-link=Empire (Hardt and Negri book) }} : {{cite book |last1=Hardt |first1=Michael |author1-link=Michael Hardt |author1-mask={{long dash}} |last2=Negri |first2=Antonio |author2-link=Antonio Negri |author2-mask= |year=2004 |title=Multitude: War and Democracy in the Age of Empire |location=London |publisher=Hamish Hamilton |isbn=978-0-241-14240-0 |ref=harv |title-link=Multitude: War and Democracy in the Age of Empire }} : {{cite journal |last=Johnson |first=Richard |year=2007 |title=Post-hegemony? I Don't Think So |journal=Theory, Culture, and Society |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=95–110 |doi=10.1177/0263276407075958 |issn=1460-3616 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Moreiras |first=Alberto |author-link=Alberto Moreiras |year=2001 |title=The Exhaustion of Difference: The Politics of Latin American Cultural Studies |location=Durham, North Carolina |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-8223-2726-4 |ref=harv }} : {{cite journal |last=Thoburn |first=Nicholas |year=2007 |title=Patterns of Production: Cultural Studies after Hegemony |journal=Theory, Culture, and Society |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=79–94 |doi=10.1177/0263276407075959 |issn=1460-3616 |ref=harv }} : {{Cite book |last=Williams |first=Gareth |year=2002 |title=The Other Side of the Popular Neoliberalism and Subalternity in Latin America |location=Durham, North Carolina |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-8223-2925-1 |ref=harv }} : {{cite journal |last=Yúdice |first=George |year=1995 |title=Civil Society, Consumption, and Governmentality in an Age of Global Restructuring: An Introduction |journal=Social Text |issue=45 |pages=1–25 |jstor=466672 |issn=0164-2472 |ref=harv }} {{refend}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin|35em|indent=yes}} : {{cite journal |last=Lash |first=Scott |author-link=Scott Lash |year=2007 |title=Power after Hegemony: Cultural Studies in Mutation? |journal=Theory, Culture, and Society |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=55–78 |doi=10.1177/0263276407075956 |issn=1460-3616 |ref=harv }} {{refend}} ==External links== * [http://www.posthegemony.org Posthegemony], a blog on "Hegemony, Posthegemony, and Related Matters" {{Portal bar|Culture|International relations|Political science|Social and political philosophy}} {{Use British English Oxford spelling|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} [[Category:Political philosophy]] [[Category:Philosophical concepts]] [[Category:Critical theory]] [[Category:Cultural studies]] [[Category:Marxist theory]] [[Category:Hegemony]] [[Category:Cultural hegemony]] [[Category:Continental philosophy]] [[Category:Marxism]] [[Category:Social theories]] [[Category:Postmodernism]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Stem]] (link changed to [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{notability|date=January 2009}}
'''Quest Learning & Assessment''' is a non-profit organization at the [[University of Texas at Austin College of Natural Sciences]] maintaining a web-based tool for instructors and students of [[mathematics]] and [[science]]. Originally created as the UT Physics Homework Service as early as 1991,<ref>[https://web2.ph.utexas.edu/utphysicshistory/UTexas_Physics_History/C._Fred_Moore.html UT Physics History of C. Fred Moore]</ref> the system was updated and moved to the College of Natural Sciences<ref>[https://cns.utexas.edu/ UT CNS]</ref> in 2002 to provide service to the broader array of [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] courses. It is being used at over 1,000 U.S. institutions; high schools as well as 2-yr/4-yr colleges and universities.<ref>[https://getquest.cns.utexas.edu/the-quest-platform/about-quest About Quest]</ref>
==Questions and Assignments== Instructors can create homework, quizzes and exams from a large pool (over 75,000)<ref>[https://getquest.cns.utexas.edu/the-quest-platform The Quest Platform]</ref><ref>[http://science.sbcc.edu/~earthsc/erin/Classes/UT%20Homework%20Service-3.htm Online Homework Service Appreciated by AHC Students and Instructors]</ref> of Mathematics, Physics, Biology, Chemistry, Physical Sciences and Computer Science questions. Most questions have built-in variations, so Quest can create custom assignments for each student. Students get immediate feedback when answering questions and can view step-by-step solutions after the assignment due date has passed.
==Grading system== The default grading system uses a "guessing neutral" system similar to the [[SAT]] grading scheme. Instructors also have the ability to set the grading system to an "item neutral" scale where points are not deducted from the assignment for failed questions. If a student gets an answer correct they are awarded points, however points are subtracted for incorrect answers to discourage guessing in both of these models. Additionally, instructors can use "One Free Try" grading in order to encourage students to re-try a question before being penalized.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://quest.cns.utexas.edu/ Official Quest site] * [https://getquest.cns.utexas.edu/ How to subscribe to Quest] * [https://wikis.utexas.edu/display/questla/Home Official Quest Documentation]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Quest Learning And Assessment}} [[Category:University of Texas at Austin|College of Natural Sciences]] [[Category:Educational software]] [[Category:Virtual learning environments]]

{{BLP sources|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | birth_name = Rangaswamy Sharath | birth_date = {{Birth date |1971|09|29}} | residence = [[Mysore|Mysore, India]] | occupation = Teacher | known_for = [[Ashtanga vinyasa yoga|Ashtanga yoga]] | spouse = Shruthi Jois | children = 2 | relatives = [[K. Pattabhi Jois]] (grandfather)
Rangaswamy (father)
Saraswati Jois (mother)
Sharmila Mahesh (sister) | website = {{URL|kpjayi.org}} }} '''R. Sharath Jois''' (born September 29, 1971) is a teacher, practitioner and lineage holder (paramaguru) of Ashtanga Yoga, in the tradition of [[K. Pattabhi Jois]]. He is the director of the Shri K. Pattabhi Jois Ashtanga Yoga Institute (KPJAYI), formerly Ashtanga Yoga Research Insttitue (AYRI)), in [[Mysore|Mysore, India]]. He is an author, the subject of several documentaries, and is known for his expertise in [[Ashtanga vinyasa yoga|Ashtanga yoga]]. ==Birth== Jois was born on September 29, 1971 in Mysore India to Saraswati Rangaswamy, daughter of K. Pattabhi Jois.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/21/world/asia/21jois.html|title=Krishna Pattabhi Jois, Leading Expert in Yoga, Dies at 93|first=Vikas|last=Bajaj|publisher=}} Jois was born into a family dedicated to the practice, preservation and teaching of Ashtanga yoga as his grandfather had learned from his teacher, [[Tirumalai Krishnamacharya|T. Krishnamacharya]]. Jois, being exposed to yoga since birth, began practicing asanas informally around seven years old and continued non-committally until age 14. At the age of 19, he began formal study of the Ashtanga yoga system with his grandfather and is the lineage holder of Ashtanga yoga today.{{cite book|last1=Donahaye|first1=Guy|last2=Stern|first2=Edwin|title=Guruji: A Portrait of Sri K. Pattabhi Jois Through the Eyes of His Students|date=September 18, 2012|publisher=North Point Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0374532833|edition=First}} Jois' grandfather, K. Pattabhi Jois, began studying yoga with T. Krishnamacharya at the age of 12, in 1927, and continued his formal study with his teacher until 1954. Pattabhi Jois spent more than 70 years of his life dedicated to practicing and teaching Ashtanga yoga. He established the Ashtanga Yoga Research Institute, his first yoga school, in his home in [[Lakshmipuram]] in 1948. To accommodate the increasing number of students coming to study, he opened a new school in Gokulam in 2002. ==Early Years - Childhood== Jois was beset by many illnesses when he was a child. When he was four years old, he contracted an infection while in Northern Karnataka, where his father was working. It turned out to be glandular fever, which required a one-year treatment. When he was seven, he fell down during the construction of Pattabhi Jois’s new yoga school, and broke his leg. The resulting bed-rest left him with low hemoglobin, which resulted in rheumatic fever. His mother, Saraswati Jois, said, "From ages four through fourteen, [it was] one thing after another."{{rp|page=120}} When Jois turned fourteen, he became focused on his scholastic education, earning a diploma in electronics from JSS in Mysore. ==First Introduction to Yoga== Jois learned his first asanas at age seven. His grandfather, K. Pattabhi Jois, used to say that young children could play with postures from the primary and intermediate series, as many of them are easy for children to do. Growing up in a house full of yoga practitioners and teachers, he was bound to do the same. ==Becoming a Teacher== When he was 19 years old, his mother told him that he should begin assisting his grandfather in the yoga shala, as there were many students, and his grandfather was not a young man anymore. From that time, he became Pattabhi Jois’s full-time assistant.{{cite web|url=http://ayny.org/guruji-sharath-saraswati/|title=Guruji, Sharath, Saraswati |publisher=Ashtanga Yoga New York}} It was during these years that Sharath’s devotion to the practice deepened and he began to intuit its transformative power. Jois studied the experiential as well as the theoretical aspects of yoga with his grandfather for quite some time before he felt that he was ready to guide others through the method. Sharath notes that it is important for a practitioner to understand the asana and the associated vinyasa before teaching others. He spent countless hours observing his grandfather teach, working with students of various body types, and developing a sense of how to work with individual differences. As a teacher, Jois reinforces the idea that practising Ashtanga yoga is a process and that asanas are simply one aspect of the practice, preparing individuals to incorporate the other limbs into their lives. There are many layers to the practice and although it may appear as a linear practice, marked by progression based on the addition of new asanas, it is in fact, much more nuanced. This is precisely why students are encouraged to focus on the physical practice because the experiential aspects of the practice are where the true learning occurs, not simply by reading about yoga theory; the practice is the foundation for the practical application of yoga theory. {{cite journal|title=Ayurveda and Health|journal=LA Yoga|date=April 2010|volume=9|issue=3|url=https://layoga.com/}} He studied under his grandfather for twenty years.{{cite book|last1=Jois|first1=Sri K. Pattabhi|title=Yoga Mala: The Original Teachings of Ashtanga Yoga Master Sri K. Pattabhi Jois|date=July 6, 2010|publisher=North Point Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0865477513|page=xiii|edition=Second}} ==International Travels== Jois began traveling internationally with his grandfather in the 1990s to teach Ashtanga yoga. They felt it was imperative to travel and teach an authentic system of yoga in the West where yoga was becoming increasingly popular and being taught in non-traditional ways. In efforts to maintain the integrity and tradition of the practice, Sharath continues to travel and teach worldwide. ==New Role as Director of KPJAYI== In 2007 when Pattabhi Jois was not in good health and unable to teach any longer, Jois became director of the Institute. Sharath has steadily grown into his role as director of KPJAYI and as the seniormost authority on the practice, having studied and practiced all six series with his grandfather. Jois' style of teaching and presence in the shala has been described by a senior student as a balance of strictness and compassion.{{cite journal|last1=MacGregor|first1=Kino|title=Ashtanga Yoga According to the Boss: An Inside Look at the Spiritual Heart of R. Sharath Jois|journal=Yoga Digest|date=January 9, 2016|pages=42–43}} In attempts to continue the parampara of yoga, Sharath holds a teachers' course in the summer for authorized and certified practitioners to ensure the Ashtanga method is being taught in the spirit of the tradition and with respect to the lineage of yoga gurus who have kept the practice alive - Rama Mohan Bramachari, T. Krishnamacharya, and K. Pattabhi Jois.{{cite news|title=Yoga Guru Sharath Jois feted by 100 senior students|agency=Star of Mysore|date=August 25, 2014}} Jois was honoured at a celebration thrown following the completion of one of the teacher’s courses in 2014. During this course, Sharath reminded his students of the importance of teaching "from the heart". Following in the spirit of his late grandfather, Jois holds conferences on Saturdays after led classes to discuss important aspects of the practice, theory, and to address any questions or concerns that students may have concerning the practice. Jois reiterates, that to receive full benefits of the practice, one should practice intentionally with the 4 D’s in mind - devotion, dedication, determination, and discipline. ==Experiments in Yoga Research== Jois has explored and highlighted different asanas for their therapeutic benefits in alleviating issues such respiratory problems,{{cite journal|title=Yoga respiratory training improves respiratory function and cardiac sympathovagal balance in elderly subjects: a randomised controlled trial.| pmid=22021757 | doi=10.1136/bmjopen-2011-000085 | volume=1| pmc=3191432| journal=BMJ Open| page=e000085 | last1 = Santaella | first1 = DF | last2 = Devesa | first2 = CR | last3 = Rojo | first3 = MR | last4 = Amato | first4 = MB | last5 = Drager | first5 = LF | last6 = Casali | first6 = KR | last7 = Montano | first7 = N | last8 = Lorenzi-Filho | first8 = G}}{{cite journal|title=Sudarshan kriya yoga: Breathing for health| pmc=3573542 | pmid=23440614 | doi=10.4103/0973-6131.105935| volume=6| journal=Int J Yoga| pages=4–10 | last1 = Zope | first1 = SA | last2 = Zope | first2 = RA}}{{cite journal|title=Effect of yoga regimen on lung functions including diffusion capacity in coronary artery disease patients: A randomized controlled study| pmc=4278137 | pmid=25558135 | doi=10.4103/0973-6131.146067| volume=8| journal=Int J Yoga| pages=62–7 | last1 = Yadav | first1 = A | last2 = Singh | first2 = S | last3 = Singh | first3 = K | last4 = Pai | first4 = P}} back pain,{{cite journal|title=Yoga as a treatment for chronic low back pain: A systematic review of the literature| pmc=4878447 | pmid=27231715 | volume=3| journal=J Orthop Rheumatol| pages=1–8 | last1 = Chang | first1 = DG | last2 = Holt | first2 = JA | last3 = Sklar | first3 = M | last4 = Groessl | first4 = EJ}}{{cite journal|title=Yoga for chronic low back pain: a randomized trial.| pmid=22041945 | doi=10.7326/0003-4819-155-9-201111010-00003 | volume=155| date=November 2011| journal=Ann. Intern. Med.| pages=569–78 | last1 = Tilbrook | first1 = HE | last2 = Cox | first2 = H | last3 = Hewitt | first3 = CE | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al}} and digestive disorders.{{cite journal|title=Irritable Bowel Syndrome: Yoga as Remedial Therapy| pmc=4438173 | pmid=26064164 | doi=10.1155/2015/398156| volume=2015| journal=Evid Based Complement Alternat Med| page=398156 | last1 = Kavuri | first1 = V | last2 = Raghuram | first2 = N | last3 = Malamud | first3 = A | last4 = Selvan | first4 = SR}}{{cite journal|title=Can yoga be used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease?| pmc=3734640 | pmid=23930033 | doi=10.4103/0973-6131.113416| volume=6| journal=Int J Yoga| pages=131–3 | last1 = Kaswala | first1 = D | last2 = Shah | first2 = S | last3 = Mishra | first3 = A | last4 = Patel | first4 = H | last5 = Patel | first5 = N | last6 = Sangwan | first6 = P | last7 = Chodos | first7 = A | last8 = Brelvi | first8 = Z}} [[Paschimottanasana]], a forward folding posture, can alleviate digestive and respiratory issues while providing stress relief by stimulating digestive fire, removing toxins and removing excess fat in the waist.{{cite web|last1=Svatmarama Yogi|title=Hatha Yoga Pradipika|url=https://pranakriya.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/HathaYogaPradipika.pdf|website=Pranakriya}} Mayurasana aids digestive processes, assuages abdominal disorders, in addition to reducing phlegm, and inflammation. In ''Ashtanga Yoga Anusthana'',{{cite book|last1=Jois|first1=R. Sharath |title=Ashtanga Yoga Anusthana |date=2014 |publisher=KPJAYI Mysore |location=Mysore |isbn=978-9351263029 |edition=Second}} Sharath demonstrates other asanas that can be practiced to aid in reducing distress caused from the aforementioned issues. Sharath has also experimented with and utilized pranayama techniques to help people suffering from a range of maladies, including respiratory issues to stress. He has experimented with unique applications of Nadi Shodhana, or alternate nostril breathing, for helping to cure serious respiratory disorders such as allergies, asthma and dysfunctions of the trachea. ==Awards, Honors, Charitable Work== * Scholarships given to students * Sharath has communicated with schools and advocated for the inclusion of yoga into the curriculum. University of Virginia campus has a traditional Mysore program run by a KPJAYI authorized teacher.{{cite web|title=Mysore Ashtanga Yoga|url=http://recsports.virginia.edu/?q=contemplative-sciences|website=University of Virginia: Contemplative Sciences Center}}{{cite web|title=University of Virginia starts Ashtanga Yoga Program|url=https://theconfluencecountdown.com/2012/10/05/university-of-virginia-starts-ashtanga-yoga-program/|website=The Confluence Countdown}} * Yoga student blood donation drive * School bag distribution for disadvantaged school children * Prosthetic limb donations * Forest conservation - Bandipur, Nagarhole * Wildlife personnel equipment - Bandipur, Nagarhole * Uttarkashi honoree bestowed title of Mahayogi Guru {{cite journal|title=Ashtanga Yoga Sadhana Retreat|journal=Namarupa: Categories of Indian Thought|date=2015|issue=Namarupa Yatra}} * Mysore Yoga honoree bestowed title of Paramaguru ==Publications== Jois published ''Ashtanga Yoga Anusthana'' which provides an introduction and overview to Ashtanga Yoga, delineating the eight limbs of the practice, the importance of Tristhana and Vinyasa, main asanas of the primary series, and supplemental asanas for therapy. * He wrote the forward to the 2010 edition of ''Yoga Mala: The Original Teachings of Ashtanga Yoga Master Sri K. Pattabhi Jois'' * Featured in LA Yoga * Featured in Namarupa magazine in interviews and articles * Written articles for Pushpam Magazine{{cite journal |last1=Jois |first1=Sharath |title=A More Spiritual Life |journal=pushpam |date=2015 |volume=A/W |issue=1}} * Featured in Yoga magazines and Indian newspapers ==Family== * Grandfather, Sri K. Pattabhi Jois (deceased 1915-2009) * Father, Rangaswamy (deceased ?) * Mother, Saraswati Jois (Mysore, India 1941- ) * Uncle, Manju Jois (Mysore, 1944-) * Uncle, Ramesh Jois (Mysore, deceased) * Sister, Sharmila Mahesh (1969-) * Wife, Shruthi Jois (1981-) * Daughter, Shraddha (2002-) * Son, Sambhav (2007-) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://kpjayi.org Shri K Pattabhi Jois Ashtanga Yoga Institute (KPJAYI)] {{DEFAULTSORT:Jois, R. Sharath}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Indian yoga teachers]] [[Category:Indian yogis]] [[Category:Scholars from Mysore]]

{{Discrimination sidebar}} '''Racial quotas''' in employment and education are numerical requirements for hiring, promoting, admitting and/or graduating members of a particular [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial group]]. Racial quotas are often established as means of diminishing racial [[discrimination]], addressing under-representation and evident [[racism]] against those racial groups or, the opposite, against the disadvantaged majority group (see [[numerus clausus]] or [[Bumiputera (Malaysia)|bhumiputra]] systems).
It has been argued that such quotas are a form of racial discrimination.
These quotas may be determined by governmental authority and backed by governmental sanctions. When the total number of jobs or enrollment slots is fixed, this proportion may get translated to a specific number.
==Regions and nations==
=== Ancient Mongolia === The [[Mongols]] divided different races into a four-class system during the [[Yuan dynasty]].
The [[List of emperors of the Yuan Dynasty|Mongol Emperor]] [[Kublai Khan]] had introduced a hierarchy of reliability by dividing the population of the Yuan Dynasty into the following classes:
*Mongols introduced it to China which at time ruled by the Mongol Empire *[[Semu]]ren, immigrants from the west and some clans of [[Central Asia]] (Muslims, Christians, Jews, Buddhists) *North Chinese, [[Kitans]], [[Jurchens]] and [[Koreans]] *Southerners, or all subjects of the former Song Dynasty
Several laws enforcing [[racial segregation]] of foreigners were passed during the [[Tang dynasty]]. In 779 AD, the Tang dynasty issued an [[edict]] which forced [[Uyghur people|Uighurs]] to wear their ethnic dress, and restricted them from marrying Chinese.
In 836 AD, Lu Chun was appointed as governor of [[Guangzhou|Canton]]. He was disgusted to find Chinese living with foreigners and [[Interracial marriage|intermarriage]]. Lu enforced separation, banning [[interracial marriage]]s, and prevented foreigners from owning properties.<ref>{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jqAGIL02BWQC&pg=PA22&dq=chinese+uighurs+779+edict+lure+canton+836+foreigners+and+chinese+lu+governor+forbade+marriages+forced+separate&hl=en&ei=SOTQTPwQgYGUB5OXibUM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=chinese%20uighurs%20779%20edict%20lure%20canton%20836%20foreigners%20and%20chinese%20lu%20governor%20forbade%20marriages%20forced%20separate&f=false|title = The golden peaches of Samarkand: a study of Tʻang exotics|author = Edward H. Schafer|year = 1963|publisher = University of California Press|location = |isbn = 0-520-05462-8|page = 22|accessdate = 2010-06-28}}</ref> The 836 law specifically banned Chinese from forming relationships with "Dark peoples" or "[[People of colour]]", terms referring to foreigners, such as "Iranians, Sogdians, Arabs, Indians, Malays, Sumatrans", etc.<ref>{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vpgVvAh2_EsC&pg=PA170&dq=836+law+tang+dynasty&hl=en&ei=ArT1TPbCK4K8lQezxoDhBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=836%20private%20intercourse%20dark%20peoples&f=false|title = China's cosmopolitan empire: the Tang dynasty|author = Mark Edward Lewis|year = 2009|publisher = Harvard University Press|location = |isbn = 0-674-03306-X|page = 170|accessdate = 2010-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=jqb7L-pKCV8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=a+history+of+chinese&hl=en&ei=MrT1TLPnJ8KclgeQ4PjfBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=snippet&q=836%20decree%20chinese%20people%20of%20colour&f=false|title = A history of Chinese civilization|author = Jacques Gernet|year = 1996|publisher = Cambridge University Press|location = |isbn = 0-521-49781-7|page = 294|accessdate = 2010-10-28}}</ref>
=== France === By 1935, the French government enacted a series of racial quotas on certain professions.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Europe’s fear of Muslim refugees echoes rhetoric of 1930s anti-Semitism|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2015/09/02/europes-current-anti-migrant-rhetoric-carries-echoes-of-1930s-anti-semitism/|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = 2015-09-02|access-date = 2015-11-21|issn = 0190-8286|language = en-US|first = Ishaan|last = Tharoor}}</ref>
=== Germany === See [[Nazi boycott of Jewish businesses]].
=== Malaysia === See [[Bumiputera (Malaysia)]].
=== United States ===
The [[National Origins Formula]] was an American system of immigration quotas, between 1921 and 1965, which restricted immigration on the basis of existing proportions of the population. The goal was to maintain the existing ethnic composition of the United States. It had the effect of giving low quotas to Eastern and Southern Europe.
Such racial quotas were restored after the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], especially during the 1970s.<ref name="'70s 242">{{cite book |title= How We Got Here: The '70s|last= Frum|first= David|authorlink= David Frum|coauthors= |year= 2000|publisher= Basic Books|location= New York, New York|isbn= 0-465-04195-7|page= |pages= 242–244|url= }}</ref> [[Richard Nixon]]'s [[United States Secretary of Labor|Labor Secretary]] [[George P. Schultz]] demanded that anti-black construction unions allow a certain number of black people into the unions.<ref name="'70s 242" /> The [[United States Department of Labor|Department of Labor]] began enforcing these quotas across the country.<ref name="'70s 242" /> After a [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] case, ''[[Griggs v. Duke Power Company]]'', found that neutral application tests and procedures that still resulted in ''de facto'' segregation of employees (if previous discrimination had existed) were illegal, more companies began implementing quotas on their own.<ref name="'70s 242" />
In a 1973 court case, a federal judge created one of the first mandated quotas when he ruled that half of the [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]] Police Department's new employees must be either black or [[Puerto Rico|Puerto Rican]].<ref name="'70s 242"/> In 1974, the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] and the [[United Steelworkers of America]] came to an agreement on the largest-to-then quota program, for steel unions.<ref name="'70s 242"/>
In 1978, the Supreme Court ruled in ''[[Regents of the University of California v. Bakke]]'' that public universities (and other government institutions) could not set specific numerical targets based on race for admissions or employment.<ref name="'70s 242"/> The Court said that "goals" and "timetables" for diversity could be set instead.<ref name="'70s 242"/> A 1979 Supreme Court case, ''[[United Steelworkers v. Weber]]'', found that private employers could set rigid numerical quotas, if they chose to do so.<ref name="'70s 242"/> In 1980, the Supreme Court found that a 10% racial quota for federal contractors was permitted.<ref name="'70s 242"/>
Then in 1991, President [[George H. W. Bush]] made an attempt to abolish [[affirmative action]] altogether, maintaining that "any regulation, rule, enforcement practice or other aspect of these programs that mandates, encourages, or otherwise involves the use of quotas, preferences, set-asides or other devices on the basis of race, sex, religion or national origin are to be terminated as soon as is legally feasible".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/11/21/us/bush-to-order-end-of-rules-allowing-race-based-hiring.html|title=Bush to order end of rules allowing race-based hiring|date=21 November 1991|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2017|via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref> This claim led up to the creation of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1991]], however the document was not able to implement these changes. It only covered the terms for settling cases where discrimination has been confirmed to have occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finduslaw.com/civil_rights_act_of_1991_pub_l_102_166|title=Civil Rights Act of 1991 - Pub. L. 102-166 - findUSlaw|website=finduslaw.com}}</ref>
[[College admissions in the United States]] have had racial quotas; see {{slink|Numerus clausus|United States}} for details. These have notably included blanket bans on [[African-American]]s, [[Jewish quota]]s from 1918 to the 1950s, and an alleged [[Asian quota]] from the 1980s and ongoing {{as of|2017|lc=y}}.
==Opposition== {{See also|Meritocracy|Equality before the law}} [[File:Protesto contra o sistema de cotas.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Students protesting against racial quotas in [[Brasília]], [[Brazil]]. The sign reads: "Want an opening? Pass the [[Vestibular]] (entry exam)!"]] Opponents of quotas object that one group is favored at the expense of another whenever a quota is invoked rather than factors such as grade point averages or test scores. They argue that using quotas displaces individuals that would normally be favored based on their individual achievements. Opponents of racial quotas believe that qualifications should be the only determining factor when competing for a job or admission to a school. It is argued this causes "[[reverse discrimination]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/reverse-discrimination.html|title=What is reverse discrimination? definition and meaning|website=BusinessDictionary.com}}</ref> where individuals in the majority to lose out to a minority.
==Examples== Some affirmative action programs openly involve quotas such as the admission program of the [[Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Jon|last=Jeter|title=Affirmative Action Debate Forces Brazil to Take Look in the Mirror|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A62685-2003Jun15?language=printer|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|date=June 16, 2003}}</ref>
The law student organization [[Building a Better Legal Profession]] has developed a method to encourage politically liberal students to avoid [[law firms]] whose racial makeup is markedly different than that of the population as a whole. In an October 2007 press conference reported in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',<ref>Amir Efrati, You Say You Want a Big-Law Revolution, Take II, "Wall Street Journal", October 10, 2007.</ref> and the New York Times <ref>Adam Liptak, In Students’ Eyes, Look-Alike Lawyers Don’t Make the Grade, ''New York Times'', October 29, 2007, https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/29/us/29bar.html?em&ex=1193889600&en=4b0cd84261ffe5b4&ei=5087%0A</ref> the group released data publicizing the numbers of African-Americans, Hispanics, and Asian-Americans at America's top law firms. The group has sent information to top law schools around the country, encouraging students who agree with this viewpoint to take the demographic data into account when choosing where to work after graduation.<ref>Henry Weinstein, Big L.A. law firms score low on diversity survey: The numbers of female, black, Latino, Asian and gay partners and associates lag significantly behind their representation in the city's population, according to a study, "Los Angeles Times", October 11, 2007, http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-diversity11oct11,1,661263.story?coll=la-headlines-california</ref> As more students choose where to work based on the firms' diversity rankings, firms face an increasing market pressure to change theirs.<ref>Thomas Adcock and Zusha Elinson, Student Group Grades Firms On Diversity, Pro Bono Work, "New York Law Journal," October 19, 2007, http://www.law.com/jsp/nylj/PubArticleNY.jsp?hubtype=BackPage&id=1192698212305</ref>
==See also== * [[Equality of opportunity]] vs [[Equality of outcome]] * [[Racism]], [[Anti-racism]] * [[Reverse discrimination]], [[Discrimination]]
'''Examples:''' *[[Affirmative Action]] *[[Diversity (business)]] *[[Jewish quota]] **''[[Numerus clausus]]'' *''[[Regents of the University of California v. Bakke]]'' *[[Reservation in India]] *[[Reserved political positions]]
'''Related:''' *[[All-women shortlists]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Racial Quota}} [[Category:Discrimination]] [[Category:Affirmative action]] [[Category:Quotas]]
[[es:Cuota de equidad]]

page.title: Recommendation Concerning the Status of Higher Education Teaching Personnel

revision.text:
The 1997 [[UNESCO]] '''Recommendation Concerning the Status of Higher Education Teaching Personnel''' is the international instrument that sets out the norms and standards for [[educator]]s working in universities and institutions of [[higher education]]. The Recommendation is the only international instrument setting out norms and standards that deals exclusively with educators within universities and institutions of higher education, and as such it is of unique importance.
== Process of Formation == The formulation process for the Recommendation involved extensive consultation with experts and member states of [[UNESCO]] (the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization). As the Recommendation concerned employment conditions, there was also extensive consultation with the [[ILO]] (International Labor Organization). The Recommendation was adopted by unanimous vote of the General Conference of UNESCO, on 11 November 1997.
In UNESCO usage, a recommendation is a formal international instrument accepted by the member states of UNESCO (UNESCO, 1981). As is generally the case with international instruments, the Recommendation is [[soft law]], that is, the enforcement of the norms and standards within the Recommendation is through the force of moral persuasion. There is, however, potential for individual governments to translate the Recommendation into hard law, through individual legislation.
The rationale for the Recommendation, as expressed in the Preamble, is that higher education plays a crucial role in both developed and developing societies. It is therefore of social importance to have specific norms and standards regarding employment and pay conditions for educators working within the higher education sector.
== Compliance with the Recommendation == There is ongoing debate as to how effective the Recommendation has been. Dr Taye Assefa (2007) and Dr [[James Page (Australian educationist)|James Page]] (2007) have recently argued that there is widespread ignorance of the Recommendation and the standards the Recommendation sets out. Dr Page suggests that a range of measures, specifically supporting legislation by individual countries, may be necessary to ensure compliance with the standards set down in the Recommendation.
== References == *Assefa, Taye. (2007) "The Status of Academic Freedom in Ethiopia." ''Peace Review: A Journal of Social Justice'' 19(4):pp. 479-485. *Page, James S. (2007) Australian Universities and International Standards: Compliance with the 1997 UNESCO Recommendation Concerning the Status of Higher Education Teaching Personnel. ''Journal of Higher Education Policy and Management'' 29(1):pp. 95-101, available on-line at [http://eprints.qut.edu.au/archive/00006628/ eprints.qut.edu.au]> *United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). 1981. ''UNESCO's Standard-Setting Instruments''. Paris: UNESCO. *United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO). 1997. ''Recommendation Concerning the Status of Higher Education Teaching Personnel''. Paris: UNESCO. online at [http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=13144&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html portal.unesco.org]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Recommendation Concerning The Status Of Higher Education Teaching Personnel}}
[[Category:UNESCO]]

revision.comment: Sanford Kwinter received a 2013 architect award from the Academy of Arts and Letters - http://artsandletters.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/2013architecture.pdf
revision.text:
<ref> http://artsandletters.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/2013architecture.pdf </ref>{{Infobox writer | name = Sanford Kwinter | image = Sanford Kwinter 03.jpg | nationality = Canadian | alma_mater = [[Columbia University]] }}
'''Sanford Kwinter''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]]-born, New York-based writer and architectural theorist, and a co-founder of Zone Books publishers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://egs.edu/faculty/sanford-kwinter|title=Sanford Kwinter - The European Graduate School|website=egs.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> Kwinter currently serves as Professor of Theory and Criticism at the [[Pratt Institute]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pratt.edu/faculty_and_staff/bio/?id=skwinter|title=Pratt Institute|website=www.pratt.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> He formerly served as an associate professor at [[Rice University]] in Houston,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mitpress.mit.edu/authors/sanford-kwinter|title=Sanford Kwinter|website=MIT Press|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> Texas, and has also taught at [[MIT]], [[Columbia University]] and [[Cornell University]] and at [[Harvard University]] Graduate School of Design.
Having received a doctorate in [[comparative literature]] from Columbia University,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.daniels.utoronto.ca/events/2014/03/07/sanford-kwinter|title=Sanford Kwinter|last=|first=|date=|website=University of Toronto|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-18}}</ref> Kwinter lectured at [[Harvard University]], the [[University of Applied Arts Vienna]] (''Universität für angewandte Kunst Wien''),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://i-o-a.at/organisation/people/sanford-kwinter/|title=IoA Institute of Architecture: Organisation / People / Sanford Kwinter|website=i-o-a.at|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> the [[Berlage Institute]] in Rotterdam,<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.theberlage.nl/persons/sanford_kwinter|title=Sanford Kwinter / Persons / The Berlage|date=2017-12-17|website=www.theberlage.nl|language=en|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> the [[Architectural Association]] in London and the [[Städelschule]] in Frankfurt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sac.staedelschule.de/en/events/sanford-kwinter-1|title=SAC - Sanford Kwinter|website=sac.staedelschule.de|language=en|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> Over the past twenty years, his publications have pioneered new ideas in art, architecture, science and the humanities.<ref name=":1" />{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} He has written widely on philosophical issues related to design, architecture, and urbanism, and was involved in the series of conferences and publications convened by [[ANY (magazine)|ANY magazine]] between 1991 and 2000.<ref name=":0" />
Kwinter has a Ph.D. from [[Columbia University]].
== Books == * ''ZONE 1/2: The Contemporary City'' (1986) MIT Press. * ''ZONE 6: Incorporations'' (1992) MIT Press. * ''Architectures of Time: Toward a Theory of the Event in Modernist Culture'' (2001) MIT Press. {{ISBN|0-262-61181-3}} * ''Far from Equilibrium: Essays on Technology and Design Culture'' (2008) Actar Press. {{ISBN|84-96540-64-2}} * ''Requiem: For the City at the End of the Millennium'' (2010) Actar Press. {{ISBN|978-84-92861-20-0}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Sanford Kwinter}} *[http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/#/people/sanford-kwinter.html Sanford Kwinter Faculty Profile at Harvard Graduate School of Design] *[http://www.staedelschule.de/architecture/79.html Städelschule Architecture Class Faculty 2008]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kwinter, Sanford}} [[Category:American architecture writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Architectural theoreticians]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Cornell University faculty]] [[Category:Harvard Graduate School of Design faculty]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology faculty]] [[Category:Rice University faculty]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{For|the conductor and opera director|Sarah Caldwell}} {{BLP sources|date=August 2018}}
'''Sara Caldwell''' (born '''Sara Chapin Coover'''; 1961 in [[New York City]]) is an American [[author]] and [[screenwriter]]/[[filmmaker]]. She was founder and producer/writer of [[Amphion Productions]] from 1991 to 2006 and is currently a co-producer and writer for House of Gorey Productions.
== Early life and education == The daughter of writer [[Robert Coover]], and Spanish needlepoint artist Pilar Sans Coover, Sara Caldwell lived in many different locations when growing up, both small towns and large cities in Guatemala, Spain, England, and various parts of the United States. She attended the progressive boarding school, [[Dartington Hall|Dartington Hall School]], in Totnes, England. Returning to America at the age of 17, she pursued a bachelor's degree in Communications from the [[University of Iowa]], where she was a member of the undergraduate [[Iowa Writers Workshop]].
== Career == After graduation, Caldwell moved to [[Chicago]], Illinois to work as a producer/writer.
Whilst in Chicago, she became involved with an inner city tutoring program, resulting in the production of her first documentary, 'Cabrini Green... what you don't see' which aired on the Chicago [[PBS]] station. She eventually became an original founder and board director for the Tutor/Mentor Connection.
Caldwell moved to [[Washington, DC]] in 1989 to work for [[WORLDNET Television and Film Service|WORLDNET]], a division of [[USIA]]. Here, she was a writer/producer for live interactive broadcasts to [[Africa]], [[East Asia]], and the [[Middle East]]. She then worked at Motion Masters in [[Charleston, West Virginia|Charleston]], WV for six months before returning to Chicago in 1991 to form Amphion Productions. She then worked as a freelance writer/producer on hundreds of projects and was a 1997 competition winner for the Chicago/Illinois Screenplay Contest. She moved her company to Los Angeles in 1998 and has since written three books on screenwriting/film production topics. She is also a professor of film/screenwriting courses at [[College of the Canyons]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.canyons.edu/Departments/MEA/Pages/Faculty.aspx|title=Faculty|last=|first=|date=|website=College of the Canyons|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 September 2018}}</ref> in [[Santa Clarita, California|Santa Clarita]], California and the Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandizing (FIDM) in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fidm.edu/en/majors/digital+media/experience/bios/sara+caldwell|title=Bios- Sara Caldwell|last=|first=|date=|website=Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 September 2018}}</ref> In 2010 she partnered with her husband Walter Gorey to form House of Gorey Productions.
In 2018, she penned her first young adult novel, ''Raven Dock'', to be published by White Bird Publications<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hometownstation.com/santa-clarita-latest-news/coc-professor-to-publish-new-young-adult-novel-raven-dock-248814|title=COC Professor To Publish New Young Adult Novel ‘Raven Dock’|last=Bernal|first=Gilbert|date=14 September 2018|website=KHTS Radio|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 September 2018}}</ref>. The novel is part of a series known as Dark Coven. She also co-wrote/produced/directed the YouTube comedy web series, ''BOOMERS''.
== Personal life == Caldwell lives in [[Valencia, Santa Clarita, California|Valencia]], California.
== Awards == Gorey Productions and Caldwell's screenplays have won awards including:
Screenplay Awards - Winner, Best Original Screenplay – Burbank International Film Festival - Best Screenplay – Shivers International Film Festival - 1st Place, Horror Category – Cannes Screenplay Contest - Best Screenplay – Dazed4Horror Film Festival, Bay City, Texas
Short Film Awards - Best Short Film – Indie Horror Film Festival, Gatlinburg, TN - Best Short Horror Film – Los Angeles Independent Film Festival - Best Short Horror Film, Best Director – Creative Arts Film Festival - Best Short Film – Los Angeles Thriller Film Festival - Audience Choice Award – Haunted Horror Film Festival, Freeport, TX
== Selected works ==
===Books===
*''Raven Dock: Dark Coven Series ('' (Austin, TX: White Bird Publications, 2018)<ref name=":0" /> *''Splatter Flicks: How to Make Low-Budget Horror Films'' (New York: Allworth Press, 2006)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://horrornews.net/24107/book-review-splatter-flicks-how-to-make-low-budget-horror-films-author-sara-caldwell/|title=Book Review: Splatter Flicks – How to Make Low Budget Horror Films|last=|first=|date=27 December 2010|website=Horror News|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=27 August 2018}}</ref> *''Jump-start your Awesome Film Company'' (New York: Allworth Press, 2005) *(with Maria-Eve Kielson) ''So You Want To Be A Screenwriter'' (New York: Allworth Press, 2000)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name}} *[https://www.houseofgoreyproductions.com Website of House of Gorey Productions] *[http://www.matchflick.com/column/1302 Interview with Sara Caldwell on her book 'Splatter Flicks'] *[https://archive.is/20070522031853/http://horror.about.com/od/reviewsnonfiction/gr/bk_splatter.htm Review of 'Splatter Flicks']
{{Authority control}}
